entries: If the tarrasque fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The tarrasque has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Reflective Carapace
entries: Any time the tarrasque is targeted by a {@spell magic missile} spell, a line spell, or a spell that requires a ranged attack roll, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 1 to 5, the tarrasque is unaffected. On a 6, the tarrasque is unaffected, and the effect is reflected back at the caster as though it originated from the tarrasque, turning the caster into the target.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The tarrasque deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Radioactive Soles
entries: The Radioactive Tarrasque gains 120 feet flying speed at its turn's start. When flying, its takeoff ignites a 30ft radius in radioactive flames, causing {@damage 15d4} fire damage and {@damage 10d4} poison damage to creatures failing a {@dc 20} Dexterity save. Its landing mimics a meteor slam within a 30ft radius, dealing {@damage 15d6} bludgeoning damage to creatures failing the same save, as it impacts the ground with force.

trait.name: Aura of Radioactivity
entries: 300 ft. from the Tarrasque.
{@b Radiant Burst}: At the Tarrasque's turn start, creatures within the aura must make a {@dc 20} Constitution save. On a fail, they take {@damage 10d6} radiant damage, or half on success.
{@b Necrotic Decay}: At the start of a creature's turn within the aura, they must make a {@dc 20} Constitution save. On a fail, they take {@damage 10d6} necrotic damage, or half on success.
{@b Radiation Sickness}: Failing any save by 5 or more causes one level of {@condition exhaustion}.
{@b Cumulative Exposure}: Each consecutive round within the aura increases save DCs by 1, resetting after 24 hours outside

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tarrasque can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes five attacks: one with its bite, two with its claws, one with its horns, and one with its radioactive Spear Generator. It can use its Swallow instead of its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}36 ({@damage 4d12 + 10}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the tarrasque can't bite another target.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d8 + 10}) slashing damage.

action.name: Horns
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) piercing damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the tarrasque's choice within 120 feet of it and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if the tarrasque is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the tarrasque's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The tarrasque makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target takes the bite's damage, the target is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the tarrasque, and it takes 56 ({@damage 16d6}) acid damage and  56 ({@damage 16d6}) necrotic damage at the start of each of the tarrasque's turns.

If the tarrasque takes 80 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the tarrasque must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the tarrasque. If the tarrasque dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 30 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Radioactive Spear Generator
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 200 ft., one target. {@h}42 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) piercing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) radiant damage and 14 ({@damage 4d6}) necrotic damage. If the attack roll exceeds the target's AC by 5 or more, the target suffers Radiation Poisoning, gaining disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws for 1 minute. A creature can make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the Radiation Poisoning on a successful save. The spear forms from where the tail would have been, but it's been mechanically modified to produce large spears of radioactive crystal.

entries: The tarrasque makes one claw attack or Radioactive spear attack

entries: The tarrasque moves up to half its speed.

The legendary tarrasque is possibly the most dreaded monster of the Material Plane. It is widely believed that only one of these creatures exists, though no one can predict where and when it will strike.

A scaly biped, the tarrasque is fifty feet tall and seventy feet long, weighing hundreds of tons. It carries itself like a bird of prey, leaning forward and using its powerful lashing tail for balance. Its cavernous maw yawns wide enough to swallow all but the largest creatures, and so great is its hunger that it can devour the populations of whole towns.

entries.name: Legendary Destruction
entries: The destructive potential of the tarrasque is so vast that some cultures incorporate the monster into religious doctrine, weaving its sporadic appearance into stories of divine judgment and wrath.

Legends tell how the tarrasque slumbers in its secret lair beneath the earth, remaining in a dormant state for decades or centuries. When it awakens in answer to some inscrutable cosmic call, it rises from the depths to obliterate everything in its path.

entries: Any creature that touches The Void Walker or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet takes 10 (3d6) acid damage.

If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw or take 14 ({@dice 4d6}) acid damage at the start of each of its turns due to a corrosive wound. Any creature can take an action to wipe off the acid, ending this effect.

entries: Recharge 5-6. The Void Walker targets one creature it can see within 30 feet. The target must succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw or be moved through a wall.

trait.name: Bathed in the Styx
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 60 feet of The Infinite Serpent must make a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw or lose thier concentration as droplets from the styx cause it to forget.

trait.name: The Infinite Serpent
entries: Every instance of damage dealt to the infinite serpent will increase its size by 5ft and its Hitpoints increase by 20.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Infinite Serpent makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}36 ({@dice 4d12 + 10}) piercing damage plus 18 ({@dice 4d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Tail

action.name: Forget {@recharge 5}
entries: The Infinite Serpent targets one creature it can see within 60 feet. The target must succeed on a DC 22 Wisdom saving throw or take 55 (10d10) psychic damage and become stunned for 1 minute as their memories are drained. The last class feature it used is removed from its memory for the next 1 hour. Target can make a Wis save at the end of thier turns to try and remember.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The Infinite Serpent makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The Infinite Serpent makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Muddled Thoughts (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Infinite Serpent targets one creature it can see within 60 feet, filling its mind with fleeting, confusing thoughts. The target must succeed on a DC 22 Wisdom saving throw or have their thoughts muddled. On a failed save, the target takes a -{@dice 2d6} penalty to their next {@dice d20} roll (attack roll, ability check, or saving throw) as the confusing thoughts momentarily cloud their judgement and focus.

trait.name: Chill of the Void
entries: Cold damage dealt by the void dragon ignores resistance and immunity to cold damage.

trait.name: Heat Death
entries: When the void dragon is killed it explodes in a swath of celestial destruction. Each creature and object within 1 lightyear of the dragon take 1100 ({@damage 200d10}) bludgeoning damage, 1100 ({@damage 200d10}) cold damage, and 1100 ({@damage 200d10}) psychic damage. Each damage type can be reduced by half with a successful {@dc 42} saving throw: Dexterity vs. bludgeoning, Constitution vs. cold, and Wisdom vs. psychic. Additionally, a creature that fails two or three of the saving throws is affected by a plane shift spell and sent to a random plane. If it is sent to the plane it currently occupies, it appears {@dice 5d100} miles away in a random direction.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (15/Day)
entries: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Galaxy of Stars
entries: A void dragon is a collection of an entire galaxy of Stars. Its size is incomprehensible and any part of it can be attacked. A meteorite, an asteroid, everything within the space of the void dragon will affect it.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragon can use its Aura of Madness. It then makes 8 attacks: 4 toss meteors, 2 toss asteroids, 1 toss moon, 1 toss planet.

action.name: Aura of Madness
entries: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is within its space must succeed on a {@dc 42} Wisdom saving throw or become afflicted with a long term {@variantrule madness} for 1 minute. A creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Toss Meteor
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 29} to hit, unlimited range, one target. {@h}70 ({@damage 20d6 + 15}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Stellar Flare {@recharge 5}
entries: As an action, the Void Dragon opens a transient portal directly to a star's core, visible within a 150-foot radius centered on a point the dragon can see within 500 feet. Brilliant solar energy and magnetic storms pour through the portal, engulfing the area in a devastating solar flare. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 42} Dexterity saving throw.

On a failed save, a creature takes 150 ({@damage 30d10}) fire damage and 150 ({@damage 30d10}) radiant damage, and is {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. On a successful save, a creature takes half damage and isn’t {@condition blinded}. The intense flare also ignites flammable objects in the area that aren’t being worn or carried, and the ground becomes scorched earth, making it difficult terrain.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The angel of judgment's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 19}). The angel can cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Change Face
entries: As a bonus action, the angel of judgment can change its face and demeanor to exhibit aspects of chaos or law, as needed by its assignment. It can have only one face active at a time and can end the effect on its turn as a bonus action.

items.name: Face of Chaos.
items.entry: The angel of judgment becomes a harbinger of chaos. It is treated as a fiend by spells and other magical effects that affect fiends and has advantage on attack rolls against celestials and devils.

items.name: Face of Law.
items.entry: The angel becomes a harbinger of law and has advantage on attack rolls against demons, fey, and undead.

trait.name: Divine Awareness
entries: The angel of judgment knows if it hears a lie.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The angel of judgement has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Penance Gaze
entries: When a creature that can see the angel of judgment's eyes starts its turn within 30 feet of the angel, the angel can force it to make a {@dc 22} Wisdom saving throw if the angel isn't {@skill incapacitated} and can see the creature. On a failure, the creature is {@condition stunned} until the start of its next turn. On a success, the creature is {@condition restrained}.

Unless surprised, a creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the angel until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at the angel in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

trait.name: Weapons of Balance
entries: The angel of judgment's weapon attacks are magical. When the angel of judgment hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra {@damage 6d8} force damage (included in the attack).

trait.name: Limited Magic Immunity
entries: The angel of judgment can't be affected or detected by spells of 6th level or lower unless it wishes to be. It has advantage on saving throws against all other spells and magical effects.

trait.name: Divine Retribution
entries: Whenever a creature hits you with an attack, it takes radiant damage equal to half the damage you take from the attack.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the angel of judgment fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The angel of judgment makes three attacks.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +15} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 4d12 + 6}) slashing damage plus 27 ({@damage 6d8}) force damage.
With faces of light and stern appraisal, these angels see both sides and render a verdict.
Angels of judgment are cosmic agents of balance. Unlike most angels, they exist to enforce equality between law and chaos. They prefer to solve disputes verbally but use force when prudent.

entries.name: Two-Faced
entries: Each angel of judgment bears two aspects: a dispassionate angel and a fiendish judge. When called to violence by the heavenly host or infernal legions, its dispassionate face changes to that of an avenging angel.

entries.name: Witnesses to History
entries: In times of turmoil and upheaval, angels of judgment watch over events. While observing, the angel is a stoic spectator, intervening only if it sees a threat to universal harmony. Even then, they prefer to send {@creature sammael|CCodex|sammael angels} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) to carry out their judgments, taking direct action only against the direst of threats.

entries.name: Cosmic Arbiters
entries: Angels of judgment arbitrate claims between the lords of righteousness and the masters of madness. If either party violates the terms, the angel destroys the offender and patiently waits for a new representative to take their place. Immortal Nature. An angel of judgment doesn't require food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Asteroid Camouflage
entries: The Asteroid Roper has advantage on Stealth checks made to hide on rocky or celestial terrain.

trait.name: Gravitational Pull
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 60 feet of the Asteroid Roper must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or have its speed reduced to 0 until the start of its next turn as they are pulled toward the Roper.

trait.name: Starlight Regeneration
entries: The Asteroid Roper regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn if it is in an environment with no atmosphere (such as outer space) and not within the area of an antimagic field. If the Asteroid Roper takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the Asteroid Roper's next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Asteroid Roper makes four attacks with its tendrils and one with its bite.

action.name: Devour
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}46 ({@dice 12d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Tendril
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 200 ft., one target. {@h}34 ({@dice 12d4 + 4}) The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the Asteroid Roper can't use the same tendril on another target.

action.name: Reel
entries: The Asteroid Roper pulls each creature {@condition grappled} by it up to 200 feet straight toward it.

action.name: Nebula Cloud
entries: The Asteroid Roper exhales a cloud of nebula-like gas in a 30-foot radius around it and moves 100ft to a new location. The area is heavily obscured for 1 minute. Any creature that starts its turn in the cloud must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw, suffering disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the start of its next turn due to disorientation.

action.name: Stellar Absorption
entries: The Roper turns its back to the sun and reflects a concentrated beam of sunlight at in a 200ft long, 20ft wide line. The Asteroid Roper regains 100 hit points. Each creature  in the line must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 8d8} radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The Roper gains additional hit points equal to half the total damage dealt to other creatures.

entries: The Asteroid Roper makes one tendril attack.

legendaryActions.name: Move
entries: The Asteroid Roper flies up to half its flying speed.

legendaryActions.name: Gravitational Surge
entries: The Asteroid Roper increases the gravitational pull for a moment. Each creature within 60 feet must succeed on a DC 19 Constitution saving throw or be stunned until the end of their next turn.

items.name: 2. Paralyzing Ray

items.name: 3. Fear Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: 4. Slowing Ray

In addition, the creature can't take reactions, and it can take either an action or a bonus action on its turn, not both. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: 5. Enervation Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: 6. Telekinetic Ray
entries: If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or the beholder moves it up to 30 feet in any direction. It is {@condition restrained} by the ray's telekinetic grip until the start of the beholder's next turn or until the beholder is {@condition incapacitated}.

If the target is an object weighing 300 pounds or less that isn't being worn or carried, it is moved up to 30 feet in any direction. The beholder can also exert fine control on objects with this ray, such as manipulating a simple tool or opening a door or a container.

items.name: 7. Sleep Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or fall asleep and remain {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute. The target awakens if it takes damage or another creature takes an action to wake it. This ray has no effect on constructs and undead.

items.name: 8. Petrification Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature begins to turn to stone and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is {@condition petrified} until freed by the  {@spell greater restoration} spell or other magic.

items.name: 9. Disintegration Ray
entries: If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw or take 45 ({@damage 10d8}) force damage. If this damage reduces the creature to 0 hit points, its body becomes a pile of fine gray dust.

If the target is a Large or smaller nonmagical object or creation of magical force, it is disintegrated without a saving throw. If the target is a Huge or larger object or creation of magical force, this ray disintegrates a 10-foot cube of it.

items.name: 10. Death Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw or take 55 ({@damage 10d10}) necrotic damage. The target dies if the ray reduces it to 0 hit points.

variant.name: Variant Abilities
entries: When a beholder's dream-imagination runs wild, the result can be an offspring that has an unusual or unique set of abilities. Rather than the standard powers of a beholder's central eye and eyestalks, the creature has one or more variant abilities—guaranteed to surprise any enemies who thought they knew what they were getting themselves into.

This section provides several alternative spell effects for a beholder's eye. Each of these effects is designed to be of the same power level as the one it replaces, enabling you to create a custom beholder without altering the monster's challenge rating. As another option, you can switch any of the damaging eye rays in the {@book Monster Manual|MM} to an effect with a different damage type, such as replacing the enervation ray with a combustion ray that deals fire damage instead of necrotic damage.

Unless otherwise indicated, an alternative ability has the same range as the eye ray it is replacing, and it affects only one creature per use (even if the ability is based on a spell that normally affects an area or multiple targets). The saving throw for an alternative ability uses the same DC and the same ability score as the spell the eye ray is based on.

entries: One glance at a beholder is enough to assess its foul and otherworldly nature. Aggressive, hateful, and greedy, these aberrations dismiss all other creatures as lesser beings, toying with them or destroying them as they choose.

A beholder's spheroid body levitates at all times, and its great bulging eye sits above a wide, toothy maw, while the smaller eyestalks that crown its body twist and turn to keep its foes in sight. When a beholder sleeps, it closes its central eye but leaves its smaller eyes open and alert.

entries.name: Xenophobic Isolationists
entries: Enemies abound, or so every beholder believes. Beholders are convinced that other creatures resent them for their brilliance and magical power, even as they dismiss those lesser creatures as crude and disgusting. Beholders always suspect others of plotting against them, even when no other creatures are around.

The disdain a beholder has for other creatures extends to other beholders. Each beholder believes its form to be an ideal, and that any deviation from that form is a flaw in the racial purity of its kind. Beholders vary greatly in their physical forms, making conflict between them inevitable. Some beholders are protected by overlapping chitinous plates. Some have smooth hides. Some have eyestalks that writhe like tentacles, while others' stalks bear crustacean-like joints. Even slight differences of coloration in hide can turn two beholders into lifelong enemies.

entries.name: Eye Tyrant
entries: Some beholders manage to channel their xenophobic tendencies into a terrible despotism. Rather than live in isolation, the aptly named eye tyrants enslave those other creatures, founding and controlling vast empires. An eye tyrant sometimes carves out a domain within or under a major city, commanding networks of agents that operate on their master's behalf.

entries.name: Alien Lairs
entries: Because they refuse to share territory with others, most beholders withdraw to frigid hills, abandoned ruins, and deep caverns to scheme. A beholder's lair is carved out by its disintegration eye ray, emphasizing vertical passages connecting chambers stacked on top of each other. Such an environment allows a beholder to move freely, even as it prevents intruders from easily creeping about. When intruders do break in, the height of its open ceilings allows a beholder to float up and harry foes on the floor.

As alien as their creator, the rooms in a beholder's lair reflect the creature's arrogance. It festoons its chambers with trophies from the battles it has won, including {@condition petrified} adventurers standing frozen in their horrified final moments, pieces of other beholders, and magic items wrested from powerful foes. A beholder judges its own worth by its acquisitions, and it never willingly parts with its treasures.
Every beholder thinks it is the epitome of beholderkind, and the only thing it fears is that it might be wrong.

entries.name: A Beholder's Lair
entries: A beholder's central lair is typically a large, spacious cavern with high ceilings, where it can attack without fear of closing to melee range. A beholder encountered in its lair has a challenge rating of 14 (11,500 XP).

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: When fighting inside its lair, a beholder can invoke the ambient magic to take lair actions. On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the beholder can take one lair action to cause one of the following effects:

items: A 50-foot-square area of ground within 120 feet of the beholder becomes slimy; that area is {@quickref difficult terrain||3} until initiative count 20 on the next round.

Walls within 120 feet of the beholder sprout grasping appendages until initiative count 20 on the round after next. Each creature of the beholder's choice that starts its turn within 10 feet of such a wall must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition grappled}. Escaping requires a successful {@dc 15} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check.

An eye opens on a solid surface within 60 feet of the beholder. One random eye ray of the beholder shoots from that eye at a target of the beholder's choice that it can see. The eye then closes and disappears.

entries: The beholder can't repeat an effect until they have all been used, and it can't use the same effect two rounds in a row.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: A region containing a beholder's lair is warped by the creature's unnatural presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Creatures within 1 mile of the beholder's lair sometimes feel as if they're being watched when they aren't.

When the beholder sleeps, minor warps in reality occur within 1 mile of its lair and then vanish 24 hours later. Marks on cave walls might change subtly, an eerie trinket might appear where none existed before, harmless slime might coat a statue, and so on. These effects apply only to natural surfaces and to nonmagical objects that aren't on anyone's person.

entries: If the beholder dies, these effects fade over the course of {@dice 1d10} days.

fluff.name: The Mesmer
entries: In the heart of a bustling city, a cloaked figure dances through the shadows, their footsteps silent against the cobblestone. With a flick of their wrist, illusions spring to life, weaving a tapestry of deception that leaves onlookers in awe and adversaries in confusion.

Amidst the chaos of battle, a serene warrior stands untouched, their enemies bewildered as their strikes meet only mirages. With a gentle whisper, the Mesmer bends the perception of friend and foe alike, shaping the battlefield with an artist’s precision and a tactician’s cunning.

Mesmers are masters of illusion, manipulation, and mental magic, blurring the lines between reality and fantasy. While some spellcasters rely on brute force or elemental power, a Mesmer’s strength lies in subtlety and finesse, influencing the world around them with delicate, yet potent, manipulations of the mind.

entries.name: The Art of Illusion
entries: To a Mesmer, reality is but a canvas for their artistry. They craft illusions with such detail and depth that even the most discerning eye can be fooled. These illusions can protect allies, ensnare enemies, or simply beguile the senses. The most skilled Mesmers can make their illusions so convincing they can inflict physical harm, blurring the lines between the mental and the material.

entries.name: Mental Dominion
entries: Mesmers wield control over minds with unparalleled grace, manipulating memories, emotions, and perceptions. They can soothe the weary, inspire the despondent, or sow chaos among their enemies. This mental dominion extends to themselves, allowing Mesmers to maintain clarity in the face of confusion and resist attempts to ensnare their own minds.

entries.name: Creating a Mesmer
entries: When creating a Mesmer, consider how they discovered their unique talents. Were they born with an innate ability to perceive the fabric of reality differently, or did they learn their skills from a mentor, honing their craft through study and practice? Think about how your character uses their abilities - do they perform in grand theaters, deceive their way through political intrigue, or employ their skills in service of a greater cause?

Consider also your character’s attitude towards their powers. Do they view their illusions as an art form, a weapon, or a tool for change? How do they feel about the ethical implications of manipulating perception and memory?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can quickly build a Mesmer by following these suggestions. First, Intelligence should be your highest ability score, followed by Charisma or Dexterity. Second, choose the {@spell minor illusion}, {@spell charm person}, and {@spell disguise self} cantrips to start embodying the Mesmer's capabilities in manipulating both mind and senses.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: As a master of illusion and mental manipulation, you can cast mesmer spells. Your magic weaves complex illusions and manipulates the minds of those around you, bending perceptions to your will and controlling the flow of battle through cunning and subtlety.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know three cantrips of your choice from the {@filter mesmer spell list|spells|class=mesmer (AGI)}. You gain additional mesmer cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Mesmer table.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Mesmer table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your mesmer spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of mesmer spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the {@filter mesmer spell list|spells|class=mesmer (AGI)}. When you do so, choose a number of mesmer spells equal to your Intelligence modifier + your mesmer level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you are a 3rd-level mesmer, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With an Intelligence of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell {@spell illusionary force}, you can cast it using a 1st-level or 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of mesmer spells requires time spent in meditation and mental exercises: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your mesmer spells, as your magic hinges on your ability to deceive, manipulate, and outsmart. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a mesmer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast any mesmer spell you know as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your mesmer spells. Mesmers often use objects that reflect their personal flair and the theatrical nature of their magic, such as mirrors, masks, or crystal orbs, as their arcane focuses. To use such an item, you must spend an hour in concentration, imbuing it with your magical essence.

classFeature.name: Replicate
entries: Harnessing your mastery over illusion, you have the unique ability to create and manipulate clones of yourself to confuse, distract, and damage your enemies. These replicas are fundamental to your tactics, providing both offensive and defensive capabilities.

entries.name: Clone Creation
entries: At 1st level, you gain the Replicate ability, allowing you to create clones. A clone mimics your actions and serves as a distraction, it has the same AC as you had at the moment it was created, having 1 hit point and causing attacks against it to be made with disadvantage. It uses your modifiers to make saving throws.

Creatures that do not have truesight, blindsight or tremorsense and can see these clones are unable to discern them from you. When they pick you as a target for an effect or an attack and there are one or more clones within range, the target is picked at random. If more than one target can be selected, multiple clones can be subject to the effect. A creature that uses an action to make a successful perception check against your Spell Save DC will be able to discern the clones that exist from you.
At any point, you can have as many clones active as your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Mirror Image
entries: Whenever you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can create a clone of yourself in an unoccupied space within 30 feet. The clone lasts for 1 minute or until destroyed.

entries.name: Decoy
entries: As a bonus action on your turn, create a clone in your space that lasts for 1 minute or until destroyed. You can then move up to your speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

entries.name: I'm The Real One!!!
entries: At the end of your turn, you can command one of your clones to make a single attack against a target within its range. Make a melee spell attack against a target within 5ft of a clone. On a hit, it deals psychic damage equal to {@dice 1d4} + your Intelligence modifier.

classFeature.name: Shatter
entries: At 2nd level, your mastery over illusions deepens, granting you the power to shatter your clones for devastating effects. Each shatter ability triggers a unique effect that scales with the number of clones you shatter.

entries.name: Shatter Style
entries: Using a bonus action, you can shatter any number of your active clones within 60 feet. The effects of shattering are enhanced by the number of clones shattered, as defined in each shatter style below.

entries.name: Mind Wrack
entries: Deal psychic damage to all enemies adjacent to each shattered clone. Damage each clone deals increases with the number of clones shattered: {@dice 1d6} for one clone, {@dice 2d6} for two clones, {dice 4d6} for three clones, doubling the dice for each additional clone shattered.
A creature adjacent to multiple clones will take a seperate instance of damage from each shattered clone.

entries.name: Cry of Frustration
entries: Shatter your clones to inflict confusion on enemies near the clones. Each creature that is adjacent to a clone must make a wisdom saving throw or be {@i confused} till the end of its next turn. Creatures next to multiple clones need to make multiple saving throws.

A {@i confused} creature on its turn is muddled with defening thoughts as the clone's cries ring out. It may use its action to focus and end the confusion. If it uses its action, bonus action, movement or reaction to do anything else while confused, it takes {@dice 1d8} psychic damage and the confusion ends. The damage taken increases with the number of clones shattered. {@dice 1d8} for one clone, {@dice 2d8} for two clones, {@dice 3d8} for three clones and so on.

entries.name: Diversion
entries: Shatter your clones to daze and disrupts your enemies. Each creature that is adjacent to a clone must make a dexterity saving throw or immediately lose thier reactions. Creatures next to multiple clones need to make multiple saving throws. If a creature was concentrating, it also needs to make a contitution saving throw to maintain concentration. The DC for which is enhanced by the number of clones you shatter. DC 10 + Shattered clones.

entries.name: Distortion
entries: Shatter your clones to and grant yourself a moment of invulnerability. You gain a pool of {@dice d6}'s that you can use to reduce damage dealt to you. The pool is as large as the number of clones shattered.
When you take damage, you can roll dice from this pool and reduce the damage by that amount after any reductions from resistance.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Illusory Onslaught
entries: At 6th level, your mastery over illusions allows you to weave them into more complex and damaging forms. Your illusions are now capable of executing a simultaneous attack, overwhelming your foes with a barrage of strikes from multiple angles.

entries.name: Enhanced Clone Attack
entries: Whenever you use your 'I'm The Real One!!!' ability to command one of your clones to attack, you can now make a second attack with another clone against the same target or a different one within range. Each attack uses your spell attack modifier and deals psychic damage equal to 1d4 + your Intelligence modifier. This ability represents your clones' enhanced capacity to harm, further blurring the line between illusion and reality.

entries.name: Tactical Reposition
entries: In addition, whenever you create a clone using any of your abilities, you can choose to swap places with any one of your existing clones on the battlefield. This swap can be triggered once per turn, allowing you to reposition strategically without provoking opportunity attacks, enhancing your battlefield mobility and deceit.

classFeature.name: Master of Mirrors
entries: At 18th level, your command over illusions allows you to manipulate the fabric of reality itself. You become a Master of Mirrors, able to create perfect reflections of reality that can harm, protect, or deceive.

entries.name: Reality's Reflection
entries: As an action, you can create a mirrored area on the battlefield up to 30 feet in diameter within 120 feet of you. This area becomes a reflection of reality for 1 minute. Enemies within the area are subjected to disorienting visions, granting advantage on attacks against them. Allies within the area receive a reflection of themselves that can take a single hit in their stead, disappearing afterward.

entries.name: Mirror Walk
entries: Once per long rest, you can step into one mirror and emerge from another within 1 mile that you have seen before. This teleportation can be used to traverse great distances instantly, escape danger, or enter secured locations.

entries.name: Ultimate Shatter
entries: You gain the ability to perform an Ultimate Shatter, instantly ending all of your active illusions and causing a massive explosion of psychic energy. Each enemy within 30 feet of a shattered illusion takes 10d6 psychic damage, and must make an Intelligence saving throw or be stunned until the end of their next turn. This ability can be used once per long rest.

classFeature.name: Quantum Illusionist
entries: At 20th level, you achieve the pinnacle of illusion mastery, becoming a Quantum Illusionist. Your understanding of reality, illusion, and the space between allows you to manipulate the fabric of existence itself, altering outcomes to your advantage.

entries.name: Quantum Flux
entries: Once per long rest, as an action, you can activate Quantum Flux. For the next minute, you gain the following benefits:
- You can reroll any attack roll, saving throw, or ability check made by you or against you, choosing the preferred outcome.
- When you or any of your allies within 60 feet of you take damage, you can use your reaction to halve that damage.
- You can teleport up to 30 feet as a bonus action on each of your turns.

entries.name: Reality Warp
entries: In addition, you gain the ability to cast the spell 'wish' once, without needing material components. After you use this ability, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

classFeature.name: Mesmer Elite Specialization
entries: At 3rd level, Mesmers choose a specialization that provides unique abilities and enhancements:

items: Chronomancer: Masters of time, Chronomancers can manipulate the flow of battle, offering abilities like speeding up ally actions or creating temporal fields that slow enemies.
Mirage: Specializing in deception, Mirages gain abilities to evade attacks, create more convincing illusions, and even make their clones perform semi-independent actions.
Illusionist: Focusing on the potency of their illusions, Illusionists enhance the durability and effects of their clones, and gain abilities that make their shattering effects more devastating.

entries.name: Choosing Your Path
entries: When you choose your specialization at 3rd level, you gain specific abilities related to that path. These abilities are designed to complement and enhance your existing Mesmer skills, providing new tactical options and strategies.

classFeature.name: Elite Specialization
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Elite Specialization.

classFeature.name: Elite Specialization

classFeature.name: Elite Specialization
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Elite Specialization.

classFeature.name: Echoes of Infinity
entries: Achieving level 21, you unlock the ability to call upon your alternate selves from different realities for assistance, manifesting the true power of a Quantum Illusionist.

entries.name: Multiversal Assistance
entries: Once per long rest, as an action, you can summon an echo of yourself from an alternate reality. This echo appears within 30 feet of you and possesses all the abilities and spells you have but cannot use 'Echoes of Infinity'. It acts on your initiative and follows your commands mentally. The echo lasts for 1 minute or until it drops to 0 hit points.

classFeature.name: Paradoxical Existence
entries: At 22nd level, your grasp on the fabric of reality allows you to blur the lines between presence and absence, existing in multiple realities simultaneously.

entries.name: Ubiquitous Presence
entries: You can spend 10 minutes to create a duplicate of yourself that lasts for 24 hours. This duplicate can perform any action you can, including spellcasting, but it cannot create another duplicate with 'Paradoxical Existence'. You can have up to two duplicates at any time, and you share a mental link, allowing you to see through their eyes and communicate.
If a duplicate is killed, you must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or suffer one level of exhaustion. Duplicates disappear if they are killed or when the duration ends.

subclassFeature.name: The Chronomancer
entries: Your mastery of deception and control over illusion magic has unveiled the true nature of the archfey, the powerful beings who govern vast regions of the Feywild, including the laws of physics and temporality within their domains. By tapping into the magic of the Feywild, you enhance your clones and gain the ability to create wells that channel this mystical energy.

subclassFeature.name: Feywild Wells
entries: {@i 3rd-level Chronomancer feature}

Your connection to the Feywild allows you to channel its magical energy into wells of the Feywild. When you create a clone, you can choose to instead to create a well where the clone was about to appear. At 3rd level you gain access to the following two wells with more as you gain levels in this subclass.

Fey Well of Protection: As an action, you can create a 10-foot-radius well at a point you can see within 30 feet. This well lasts for 1 minute. Allies within the well have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects and gain temporary hit points equal to your Mesmer level at the start of each of their turns. You can use this feature once per short or long rest.

Fey Well of Illusions: As an action, you can create a 10-foot-radius well at a point you can see within 30 feet. This well lasts for 1 minute. Enemies within the well have disadvantage on saving throws against your spells and illusions. Additionally, illusions you create within the well are semi-tangible, allowing them to interact with the environment and creatures. These illusions can support up to 10 pounds of weight and have disadvantage on checks to see through them. You can use this feature once per short or long rest.
